title: Trump Says Putin, Zelenskiy Must Be Flexible
description: On the early edition of Balance of Power, Bloomberg Washington Correspondent Tyler Kendall and Senior Editor Michael Shepard discuss next steps in the peace process between Russia and Ukraine. On today's show, former United Kingdom Ambassador to the United States Peter Westmacott, Center for the Study of the Presidency and Congress Senior Democracy Fellow Jeanne Sheehan Zaino, BGR Group International Practice Partner Lester Munson and former Deputy National Security Advisor for Cyber and Emerging Technology in the Biden Administration Anne Neuberger. (Source: Bloomberg)

Welcome to our to a balance of power. On Bloomberg. As Bloomberg News reports, work has started already between U.S. and European officials on potential security guarantees for Ukraine. I'm Tyler Kendal here alongside Bloomberg's Michael Shepard in Washington. Joe, Matthew is off and we have a busy afternoon ahead. We'll bring you all of the updates, including an interview with Sir Peter Westmacott, former U.K. ambassador to the United States. Once again, your hosts, Tyler Kendal and Michael SHAPIRO. Charlie Pellet in New York for us. Thank you, as always. If there is a deal that is one that can be relied upon to be fair and lasting. Can we just dig down a little bit more on what this credible deterrence framework, what the look like? And as you're talking about the different sort of aspects that we could see, we keep hearing this idea about air cover and perhaps this is an area where the US would be pushing forward the most here. Can you give us some insight into how these negotiations are happening behind closed doors when it comes to what the U.S. would actually supply to a security guarantee to make sure that a potential deal would actually get through? Well, there's a lot of discussions still going on. There's a coalition of the willing meeting that was co-chaired by the French president and the British prime minister, I think today. There are military chiefs getting together in Washington. I think there's a lot of the detail of what it really means that has got to be worked out. But we do know from president's intensity that he would like to have I think he said ten different Patriot missile systems on Ukrainian territory. These are very expensive, but they are super effective and they are a very important part of the defense of Ukraine against ballistic missiles and other Russian hardware which might be fired there. Then I think other parts of it would be territorial guarantees. The president's talked about something that is Article five. In other words, an attack on one country is an attack on us all. That is to say that if Ukraine was attacked, then the coalition of the willing, if not NATO members themselves, would have regarded themselves as duty bound to come to help Ukraine. But there's an awful lot of detail on this military side that's got to be hammered out. And I'm not sure that President Trump is very clear where he wants it to be, but he has understood that there will not be a deal unless there is something like that. And there is an arrangement whereby Ukraine can have its own credible military deterrent and equipment to withstand any further attacks, because ultimately nobody trusts Putin to keep his word. Perhaps President Trump does, but nobody else does. Anyone who's dealt with him knows that, as we saw on the eve of the invasion of Ukraine, he lies through his teeth. So there's got to be something which is, you know, pretty strong and pretty credible. If the Ukrainian people in the Ukrainian government are to go along with it. Sir Peter, one thing President Donald Trump has made clear is his desire to move very quickly with this and outlined together with European leaders yesterday, a timetable of perhaps a bilateral meeting between the Russian and Ukrainian leaders within two weeks and perhaps a trilateral meeting, including him within three weeks. Is that overly optimistic and what are the risks of moving at this pace? Well, one of the benefits of having somebody like President Trump in the Oval Office is that he likes to move fast. So these territorial issues, as well as the military guarantees and the broader political questions that we've touched on, this does take time. But President Trump is a man in a hurry.
